greeting: Greetings from The On-Line Encyclopedia of Integer Sequences! http://oeis.org/

results.name: Numbers n such that the Matula tree of n is a binary tree (i.e., root has degree 2 and all nodes except root and leaves have degree 3).
comment: This sequence should probably start with 1. Then a number n is in the sequence iff n = 1 or n = prime(x) * prime(y) with x and y already in the sequence. - _Gus Wiseman_, May 04 2021
link: Charles R Greathouse IV, Table of n, a(n) for n = 1..186
Keith Briggs, Matula numbers and rooted trees
F. Goebel, On a 1-1-correspondence between rooted trees and natural numbers, J. Combin. Theory, B 29 (1980), 141-143.
D. Matula, A natural rooted tree enumeration by prime factorization, SIAM Rev. 10 (1968) 273.
Index entries for sequences related to Matula-Goebel numbers
formula: The Matula tree of n is defined by as follows (p_m denotes the m-th prime):
... for each prime factor m of n:
...... add the subtree matula(p_m), by an edge labeled m
example: The sequence of trees (starting with 1) begins:
program: (PARI) list(lim)=my(v=List(), t); forprime(p=2, sqrt(lim), t=p; forprime(q=p, lim\t, if(i(p)&&i(q), listput(v, t*q)))); vecsort(Vec(v)) \\ _Charles R Greathouse IV_, Mar 29 2013
xref: The semi-binary version is A292050 (counted by A001190).
The semi-identity case is A339193 (counted by A063895).
The semi-identity plane tree version is counted by A343663.
A000081 counts unlabeled rooted trees with n nodes.
A276625 ranks identity trees, counted by A004111.
A306202 ranks semi-identity trees, counted by A306200.
A306203 ranks balanced semi-identity trees, counted by A306201.
A331965 ranks lone-child avoiding semi-identity trees, counted by A331966.
